guide.title: ProjectXML documentation
guide.abstract: This page describes project xml, the format for describing project pages.

body.p: This new format is created to allow for an automatically buildable project overview.
The project.xml file has as its purpose simplify project page editing while simultaneously allowing for easy access by programs or xslt scripts.
A project.xml should start with the following lines:
body.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?xml-stylesheet href="/xsl/project.xsl" type="text/xsl"?> <?xml-stylesheet href="/xsl/guide.xsl" type="text/xsl"?> <!DOCTYPE project SYSTEM "/dtd/project.dtd">
body.p: The file starts with a project
A projectxml file can contain a number of tags:

ti.p:
<!ELEMENT project (name, longname?, description, longdescription, goals?, (dev | resource | subproject |extraproject | extrachapter | herd)* )>
This is the root element of a project.xml file. It has no attributes.

<!ELEMENT name (#PCDATA)>
The name of the project. This is the short name, and should have no spaces

<!ELEMENT longname (#PCDATA)>
The name of the project. This is a longer name. It can have spaces and is used where longer names are appropriate

<!ELEMENT description (#PCDATA)>
A short description of the project. This project is used externally, and as abstract in the right column of a guide.xml page

<!ELEMENT longdescription (%all.class; | #PCDATA)>
A long description of the project. The contents of this tag will be used as contents of the resulting guidexml body tag, and all things allowed in guidexml bodies is allowed in this tag

<!ELEMENT goals (%all.class; | #PCDATA)>
Here the goals of the project should be described the project. The contents of this tag will be used as contents of the resulting guidexml body tag, and all things allowed in guidexml bodies is allowed in this tag

<!ELEMENT dev (#PCDATA)>
<!ATTLIST dev role CDATA "member"
description CDATA #IMPLIED>
The dev tag is used to specify the developers who are members of the project. It has two attributes. The first one is role, it is supposed to specify the role of the developer. There must be exaclty one that has the value lead. This is for the developer who leads the project. This attribute is supposed to contain standardized roles.
The description attribute can be used for more informal and clarifying descriptions of the developer, here things like Chief kernel guru are allowed
ti.note: only text is allowed within this element. It must be the nick of the developer
The role is standardized. So a subproject lead would be subproject lead, the project can be mentioned in the description

ti.p:
<!ELEMENT resource (#PCDATA)>
<!ATTLIST resource link CDATA #IMPLIED>
The resource tag can be used to specify resources offered by the project. The contents of the tag are the description of the specific resource. The link attribute is used to specify the url of the resource

<!ELEMENT subproject EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST subproject ref CDATA #REQUIRED
inheritmembers ( yes | no ) "no" >
The subproject tag is used to specify where the projectxml file of a subproject can be found. Due to the limitations of xml this needs to be an absolute path (if someone has a solution, please let me know). It has no contents, but has two attributes.
The first parameter, ref is a required parameter that specifies the location of the subproject. The second parameter inheritmembers is used to specify whether subproject members are to be considered members of this project too. It defaults to no.

In the result of the transformations (the webpage) the data of the subproject will be gotten from that subprojects xml file. As an error in that file results in the failure of this projects display, make sure that the page of the subproject is correct.

<!ELEMENT extraproject (#PCDATA | %all.class; )*>
<!ATTLIST extraproject name CDATA #REQUIRED
lead CDATA #IMPLIED >
The extraproject tag can be used for projects without project pages. This tag only allows for the lead to be specified, not other members. The content of this tag is a description of the project. This tag has two attributes. The first name is required and gives the name of the project. This has the same constraints as the name tag. The second attribute lead is used to specify the lead of the project

<!ELEMENT plannedproject (#PCDATA | %all.class; )*>
<!ATTLIST plannedproject name CDATA #REQUIRED >
The plannedproject tag can be used for planned projects. The content of this tag is a description of the project. This tag has one attribute. The attribute name is required and gives the name of the project. This has the same constraints as the name tag.

<!ELEMENT extrachapter (title, section+)>
<!ATTLIST extrachapter position ( top | bottom |subproject|goals ) "bottom">
The extrachapter is a special tag. It is functionally the same as the chapter tag of guidexml. It can be used to add arbitrary chapters to the project page. It has the same syntax. It has one attribute position that can be used to specify where the chapter needs to be inserted in the page. The value top will have it appear below the introduction. The value goals will have it appear below the goals chapter, etc.

<!ELEMENT herd EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST herd name CDATA #REQUIRED>
The herd tag finally is used to specify the herds that are managed by this project. Herds managed by the subprojects should not be included here. It has no content and one required attribute: name which should refer to a herd name in the herds.xml file.
